overview_of_class: This course will examine the nature and determinants of such things as international capital flows, exchange rates and currency crises. The aim will be to help students think clearly about these issues using simple and widely applicable models. There will necessarily be a significant theoretical component to the course, but the aim will be to link the theory to real-world events whenever possible.
name: International Finance
title: WCAS ECON 362-0-20 International Finance

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will examine the nature and determinants of such things as international capital flows, exchange rates and currency crises. The aim will be to help students think clearly about these issues using simple and widely applicable models. There will necessarily be a significant theoretical component to the course, but the aim will be to link the theory to real-world events whenever possible.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Econ 201, 202, 281, 310-1, 311, Math 220, Stats 210. Students should be comfortable with basic differential calculus.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Two lectures a week, plus a possible TA section.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: One midterm and a final, which will together count for at least 50% of the final grade. The remainder will come from assignments, the number of which will depend on the size of the class.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: There is not an assigned textbook. There will instead be some supplied assigned readings that will come from other sources, such as articles and supplementary notes.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: A suggested textbook is International Economics: Theory and Policy, by Krugman and Obstfeld, 8th Edition (ISBN: 978-0321493040). But this book is not necessary unless you really feel you need the material in tandem with the articles and supplementary notes supplied during class.

subject: ECON
